page.lettertext:
fol.205r
To the L. Chance
l
:
L. Th
re
r and
to
e L. Buckhurst
May it please yo
r
good LL: By o
r
last of the xxij
th
of this p
nt
e we signifyed
how farre we had proceaded w
th
the
States g
en
all
upon the poynt
of
Instrucc
o
ns propounded unto them, Imediately after the dispatch of which
L
re
s wee pressed agayne some better resoluc
o
n to o
r
first proposic
o
ns./
wherunto they answered, that unles we woulde declare in wrytinge the
reasons of o
r
mislyke of their answeres, and o
r
objections, to their Apostylles
they mighte not well proceade to any further consultac
o
n, havinge allredy
deli
v
ed as much as might be yelded unto, consideringe the p
nt
e State of their
Cuntry and affayres. Hereupon to avoide losse of tyme we p
nt
ely framed
some fewe objections in wrytinge to the most materiall poynt
of their apostyll
w
ch
we deli
v
ed in their assembly, enlarginge the same by speeches as wee
thowghte convenient for their better inducem
t
to allowe of o
r
demaundes; and
w
th
all did exhibite the rest of the matters we had to propound all at once
to the ende we mighte receave some speedy answere to the whole
The xxiij
th
we receaved from them an acte sent unto us by
Arsens
their
Secretary signyfyinge their Intention to sende or reporte to their Provinc
aswell o
r
objections, as o
r
seconde proposic
o
ns, and therfore desyred of us, if
we had any other thinge in chardge that mighte requyre their Answere, we
woulde vowchsafe to deliver it alltogether to be Im
pt
ed
to
w
th
the rest to their
Superio
rs
, whose myndes and resoluc
o
ns they purposed to have upon the
whole matters of o
r
negotiac
o
n./
Wee mervaylinge greatly at this determinac
o
n of the States to send againe
to their provinc
and therby to detracte the tyme, havinge by their acte
declared a sufficiency of aucthoritye in themselves to treate and conclude
w
th
us upon the matters of o
r
chardge, we resorted unto them, and deli
v
ed
o
r
opinions how needeles it was for them to take that course, in respecte that
by the xix
th
article of the Treatye, there was allredy graunted to her
Ma
tye
, and to the
Counsell of Estate
, full pow
r
and aucthoritye for th'establishing
of all thing
that did concerne the good of the comon weale, or matters
of their martiall discipline, and that o
r
second
posic
o
ns tended in effecte
but to an explanac
o
n of that article./ This article we did purposely
from the begynnynge forbeare to urge supposinge that they of themselves
in their answeres unto us would allwayes have had considerac
o
n thereof:
But such was ether their oversighte in not c
o
sideringe the Substance of
the Article, or their skyll and cunnynge, advisedlye to omitte the same
as when they perceyved us resolutely to presse the Substance of that
article, they ryse from the Table in a sort amazed, and retyred them
selves into another roome, to advyse upon their answere, where after
they had conferred more then a quarter of an hower, they returned and
by their president
John Vanderwarke
one of the deputed for
Zealand
,
they deli
v
ed, that for so much as her Ma
tie
had refused the So
v
ainty of
their Provync
beinge offred unto her, they supposed shee would not
now seeke
/
fol.205v
now seeke it by vertue of the Contracte: That to have more heades or
So
v
aignes in their State then
anie
one was to make the same a monster:
that the aucthority graunted to her Ma
ty
by this article was to be exercysed
but for one tyme only, w
ch
was allredy executed by the c
o
mynge of the
Earle of Leycestre
, as her Ma
t
generall in
to
these Cuntryes, and that there-
fore the effecte of that article was allredy
formed, and the article
vanished. Wee disprooved their conceipt of any purpose of demand
of soverainty in her Ma
tie
, by requyringe the auctority yelded by that
Article, and declared that the same was not graunted to her Ma
ty
alone
but to her & the counsell of Estate Jointly who were all their c
o
patriot
&
of their owne body syllected and chosen by the se
v
all Provinc
, as
sons to
whom the exercyse of their soverainty was c
o
mytted, and such as in for
m
tymes w
th
the go
v
no
rs
of their Provinc
ever injoyed the lyke auctority
under their Princ
./ We lykewise disproved their construcc
o
n made of
the article by c
o
paringe the sence therof w
th
the whole body of the treaty,
and made it appeare unto them that the same was no more extincte then
the rest that c
o
tinued in beinge, and so prosecuted the confirmac
o
n therof
by as many argum
t
as we coulde. In the ende after longe debatinge,
and no alterac
o
n of their conceipt and opinion towchinge th'explicac
o
n
of the Article appearinge, we were forced to use (thoughe in temperate
ma
n
) some round speeches unto them signifyinge how sory we were
to disco
v
their backward affections to her Ma
tie
so clerely manifested by
this c
o
ference./ They protested ne
v
theles their great devoc
o
n to
her Ma
tie
, and fynally prayed that what they had sayde to the purpose
of the Article might not be taken as an answere, but that they would
Impart o
r
allegac
o
ns to their
vinc
and receave their sensure and
resolucon to the saide Article: wee suspectinge
what
what the Provinc
mighte resolve, upon their construcc
o
n to be made of the sence of the said
Article, answered that if they meante to put the matter in deliberac
o
n
amonge their Provinc
, we woulde in lykesorte rec
o
mende the same to the
Interpretac
o
n of yo
r
LL: and the rest that were in C
o
myssion from her
Ma
tie
in concludinge the Treatye, wherof it may please yo
r
LL: to have
good c
o
siderac
o
n and (if it may so seeme good unto yo
u
) that the opinions
of some of the best learned in the Civyll Lawe in
England
may be taken
upon the Substance of the Article, and signifyed hither w
th
yo
r
LL
construcc
o
n of the same, that they may not evade from us in this poynte
the rather for that we
ceyve we shall hardly establishe any sufficient
aucthoritye in the Go
v
no
r
and Counsell of Estate here, if we yeld to the
Anullinge of that Article
bes
being certenly informed that some of this
assembly have allredy before hande given
Caveats
to their Provinc
to beware how they accorde to the go
v
no
r
and Counsell of Estate the
pow
r
given by the c
o
tracte, bycawse they shall therin yeld them regall
auctority, w
ch
by the States generall is challenged by tradition from the
people to remayne in them, and can by no meanes Indure that a go
v
no
r
from her Ma
tie
w
th
the Counsell should be Invested w
th
that aucthoritye
from
But
fol.206r
But their
Reces
(as they terme it) to their Provinc
there, wylbe much dayly
used, and is in o
r
Conceipt
done of purpose to win tyme that they may see what
Successe may happen in
Fraunce
, if the
K
. become possessed of
Paris
,
accordinge
wherunto they will streighten or enlardge themselves, in allowinge the demand
made by her Ma
tie
, not that they will hastly become Frenche, but that they
shall therby discern how the enemye may be Imployed and hindred from
any notable attempte against them and so measure their owne necessity to
be releeved by her Ma
tie
./
The resoluc
o
ns that shall now be drawen from the Provinc
to the matters wee
have propounded wyll yeld by the answeres therunto of the States so absolute,
as o
r
further replyes or objections will nothinge alter the same, or prevayle
to amend or reforme any Jote of their determinac
o
n havinge allredy at great
lengthe in many meeting
deli
v
ed as much and as many reasons on her Ma
ts
te as (in o
r
poore opinions in the knowledge wee have of the p
nt
e state of
these Cuntryes and humo
rs
of the men) may be saide to the se
v
all matters we
have delivered: and therfore now after we shall have c
o
ferred w
th
the Counsell
of Estate (to whom we meane to repayre to
Arnhem
)
I Thomas Wylk
shall
have nothinge to do here, but to attend the answere from the Provinc
and
States w
ch
I looke to receave abowte the ende of Septemb
r
nexte and not before.
In the meane tyme foreseeynge the Event hereof I motioned unto the States (
as
as of my self that they would lyke of my Repayre into England, pretendinge
some perticular cawse of myne owne, and to returne hither at suche tyme
as I mighte understand from them of their resoluc
o
ns taken in the poynt
of
my negotiation, wherunto they would in no sort condiscend, but entreated
me to staye, for that they desyred to growe to some conclusion upon the
condic
o
ns I had delivered concerning the trade to
Spayne
.
Our purpose of c
o
ference w
th
the Counsell is to move them to Joyne w
th
us in clayminge the auctoritye graunted by the Contracte, and becawse I
Thomas Bodley by the knowledge I have of their disposic
o
ns do thincke they
wylbe hardly Induced to concurre w
th
us publickly in that behalf, by reason
they are for the most
te unwyllinge to offend the States as fearinge to
be removed from their plac
or otherwise disgraced, we entend to urge
them upon their othe taken for the observance of the c
o
tracte: and
therin nevertheles to be advised, and to use such course and discrec
o
n as
may best further the cawse and least offend the one or the other, untyll
it may be seene what shalbe resolved and answered to o
r
posic
o
ns.
Thus farre for the matter of o
r
Instrucc
o
ns, wherin we do
test unto
yo
r
LL upon o
r
alleageance to the Q. Ma
tie
we have travailled and ende
v
ed
all that wee may, not only
w
th
in
o
r
publicke coferenc
w
th
the States in
generall but w
th
the cheefest of them in
ticuler, and can not for
o
r
lyves fore Judge what successe will followe of o
r
acc
o
ns herein, such
and so strange hath bin the ma
n
of their
ceadinge w
th
us, using
both
fol.206v
Both roughe and mylde c
o
municat
o
n w
th
them thoughe w
th
owt offence./
We receaved from the Lieuten
a
te Go
v
no
r
of the
Bryll
a L
re
dated the xxv
th
of this p
nt
e advertisinge that the victuallo
r
havinge browght corne to
the Towne for the provision of the Garrison where the Orders are
now to be put in execuc
o
n the Bourghm
rs
of the Towne have Inhibited
that nether the myllers shall grynde the corne, nor the Bakers bake
the same, wherby there appeareth a resoluc
o
n in the people to oppose
themselves against that
te of the orders for victuellinge of the
Soldio
rs
: and becawse for some reasons alleaged in o
r
for
m
L
res
, we thincke
it not fytt at this tyme to make any garboyle betwixt the Towne
and the Garrison we have thought good to advertise the Lieuten
a
te
governo
r
to forbeare the execuc
o
n of the orders in that poynt untyll
yo
r
LL
mighte be advertised of this opposition (w
ch
we conceyve to
growe underhand from the States) that we might receave yo
r
plesure
and direction therein. And truly my LL
we fynd both by the States
and by the Townes (who sythence we began to treate here have sent
unto us their Boroughm
rs
and principall officers to pray that the
victuallinge might be forborn) that it is so offensyve to the Inhi
b
ant
of the Townes as it wyll breed a great alienac
o
n of the people from
her Ma
tie
. For the apparrell of the Soldiers the States & Townes do
not much myslyke, and to the Soldier himself there is nothinge more
offensyve then the victuall w
ch
(as they complayne in all the
garrisons) is not only very corrupt but sould unto them at higher
rates then is afforded by the Townes: and what further Inconvenienc
doe growe therof wyll best appeare unto yo
r
LL
by the Articles lately
sent unto you from the governo
r
and Cap
ens
of
Bergen
wherw
th
we
have bin made acquaynted and fynde them all worthy of considerac
o
n
w
ch
wee most humbly Referre to yo
r
good Lo:
And so take o
r
Leave from the
Haghe
the xxix
th
of July.
1590
.
